message_1: Suppose the population mean of heights of adult males in a certain city is 175 cm with a standard deviation of 5 cm. If a sample of 50 adult males is taken from this city, what is the probability that the sample mean height is between 174 cm and 176 cm?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the Central Limit Theorem, which states that the sampling distribution of the sample mean approaches a normal distribution as the sample size increases, regardless of the shape of the population distribution.

Given the population mean (μ) is 175 cm and the population standard deviation (σ) is 5 cm, we can find the standard deviation of the sample mean (σx̄) using the formula:

σx̄ = σ / √n

where n is the sample size.

In this case, n = 50, so:

σx̄ = 5 / √50 ≈ 0.7071 cm

Now, we want to find the probability that the sample mean height (x̄) is between 174 cm and 176 cm. To do this, we will use the z-score formula:

z = (x̄ - μ) / σx̄

First, we will find the z-scores for 174 cm and 176 cm:

z₁ = (174 - 175) / 0.7071 ≈ -1.4142
z₂ = (176 - 175) / 0.7071 ≈ 1.4142

Now, we will use a standard normal distribution table (also known as a z-table) to find the probabilities corresponding to these z-scores. 

P(z₁) ≈ 0.0786
P(z₂) ≈ 0.9214

Finally, we will find the probability that the sample mean height is between 174 cm and 176 cm by subtracting the probabilities:

P(174 < x̄ < 176) = P(z₂) - P(z₁) = 0.9214 - 0.0786 ≈ 0.8428

So, there is approximately an 84.28% probability that the sample mean height of 50 adult males from this city will be between 174 cm and 176 cm.
